title: 110_hr5513
content: The Act titled "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18, and possession by minors in public places. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" mandates that states must prohibit the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and their possession in public places. Law enforcement agencies must notify parents if a minor is found purchasing or possessing tobacco products. Retailers must implement a program to educate employees on tobacco product distribution within 180 days of the law's enactment. The Act mandates states to prohibit the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and their possession in public places. Employers must educate employees on compliance with the law and verify age before selling tobacco products. The Act requires states to enforce a ban on selling tobacco to individuals under 18 and their possession in public places. Violators may face penalties and community service. Some states have delayed implementing this requirement until fiscal year 2012. The Act mandates states to enforce a ban on selling tobacco to individuals under 18 and their possession in public places. States must establish goals for reducing retailer violations of the law through annual inspections, with decreasing violation rates each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014. The Act requires states to enforce a ban on selling tobacco to individuals under 18 and reduce availability to minors. Violation rates must decrease annually from 2012 to 2020. The Act mandates states to enforce a ban on selling tobacco to individuals under 18 and reduce availability to minors through random inspections and annual reports to the Secretary. The State seeking a grant must demonstrate success in meeting goals to reduce tobacco availability to minors and outline enforcement strategies for the upcoming fiscal year. Funding agreements allow states to use individuals under 18 for compliance inspections. The State can engage individuals under 18 for compliance inspections with written consent and direct supervision. State settlement proceeds must be used for health expenditures. The Secretary determines State compliance with tobacco control and cessation activities before granting funds under section 1921. Noncompliance results in a reduction of the allotment for the fiscal year. The Secretary reduces the allotment under section 1921 for the State based on the percentage determined under section 1933 for each fiscal year, starting at 10% for 2010 and increasing by 10% each year until reaching 40% for fiscal year 2013 and beyond. The Secretary may reduce the allotment under section 1921 for the State by 10% to 40% based on compliance with specified subsections. Additionally, the Secretary will provide assistance to States in implementing the required programs. The Secretary will assist States in implementing State laws by developing model legislative language and providing technical guidance. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined in the section. The effective date of the amendment is specified for the first applicable fiscal year. The effective date of the amendment applies to the first applicable fiscal year and subsequent years. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in the section. SEC. 3.
